content.html:
In this unit, students will:

  • Identify quadratic functions from expressions, tables, and graphs.
  • Represent quadratic equations in standard and factored form.
  • Graph quadratic equations from standard form, factored form, and vertex form.
  • Describe how the \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) in \(ax^2 + bx + c\) affect the graph of a quadratic equation.
  • Determine whether a visual pattern represents a linear, exponential, or quadratic relationship.

To accomplish these unit-level learning goals, students will complete the following lessons and activities.

Lesson Number

Lesson Title

Associated TEKS

Unit 7, Section A Overview: A Different Kind of Change

7.1

Patterns of Change

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.2

Introduction to Quadratic Relationships

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

Unit 7, Section A Quiz

Unit 7, Section B Overview: Quadratic Functions

7.3

Building Quadratic Functions from Geometric Patterns

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\)

7.4

Comparing Quadratic and Exponential Functions

A12(B) evaluate functions, expressed in function notation, given one or more elements in their domains

7.5

Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations (Part 1)

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.6

Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations (Part 2)

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.7

Building Quadratic Functions to Describe Situations (Part 3)

A6(A) determine the domain and range of quadratic functions and represent the domain and range using inequalities

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

Unit 7, Section B Quiz

Unit 7, Section C Overview: Working with Quadratic Expressions

7.8

Equivalent Quadratic Expressions

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\)

7.9

Standard Form and Factored Form

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\)

7.10

Graphs of Functions in Standard and Factored Forms

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\)

Unit 7, Section C Quiz

Unit 7, Section D Overview: Features of Graphs of Quadratic Functions

7.11

Graphing from the Factored Form

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

A7(B) describe the relationship between the linear factors of quadratic expressions and the zeros of their associated quadratic functions

7.12

Graphing the Standard Form (Part 1)

A7(B) describe the relationship between the linear factors of quadratic expressions and the zeros of their associated quadratic functions

A7(C) determine the effects on the graph of the parent function \(f(x)=x^2\) when \(f(x)\) is replaced by \(af(x)\), \(f(x)+d, f(x-c)\), \(f(bx)\) for specific values of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\)

7.13

Graphing the Standard Form (Part 2)

A6(B) write equations of quadratic functions given the vertex and another point on the graph, write the equation in vertex form \(f(x)=a(x-h)^2+k\), and rewrite the equation from vertex form to standard form \(f(x)=ax^2+bx+c\)

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

A7(B) describe the relationship between the linear factors of quadratic expressions and the zeros of their associated quadratic functions

A7(C) determine the effects on the graph of the parent function \(f(x)=x^2\) when \(f(x)\) is replaced by \(af(x)\), \(f(x)+d, f(x-c)\), \(f(bx)\) for specific values of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\)

7.14

Graphs That Represent Situations

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.15

Vertex Form

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.16

Graphing from the Vertex Form

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

7.17

Changing the Vertex

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry

A7(C) determine the effects on the graph of the parent function \(f(x)=x^2\) when \(f(x)\) is replaced by \(af(x)\), \(f(x)+d, f(x-c)\), \(f(bx)\) for specific values of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\)
